{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14108,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Saxifraga rotundifolia prefers consistently moist but not waterlogged soil. Water the plant regularly, especially during dry spells, ensuring the soil remains damp to part-dry between watering sessions. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so well-draining soil is essential. During the growing season in spring and summer, it may require more frequent watering, while in the dormant period of fall and winter, you can reduce the amount of water. Always check the top inch of soil and water when it feels dry to the touch."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Saxifraga rotundifolia thrives in partial to full shade, making it an excellent choice for shady garden spots. It can handle some morning sun, but direct midday sun should be avoided as it can scorch the leaves. Ideally, aim for dappled sunlight if planting under trees or in gardens with filtered light. In overly shaded areas, flowering might be reduced. Hence, find a balance with a spot that receives either indirect light or partial sun for at least a portion of the day to help the plant thrive and flower well."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Saxifraga rotundifolia is generally minimal, focusing on removing any dead or damaged leaves to keep the plant tidy and healthy. After the flowering season, you can deadhead the spent flowers to encourage more blooms and prevent self-seeding if that is not desired. Prune any sprawling growth that detracts from the plant's overall appearance. Regularly cleaning up around the plant helps to prevent disease and pest infestations. Always use clean and sharp pruning tools to prevent transmitting diseases."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Round-leaved Saxifrage","description":"Saxifraga rotundifolia, common name round-leaved saxifrage, is a flowering herb and alpine plant of the genus Saxifraga.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Europe"],"other_name":["Round-leaved Saxifrage"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Saxifraga rotundifolia"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Gravelly"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":13304,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Malva neglecta prefers moderate watering. It thrives well when the soil is kept evenly moist but not waterlogged. During its growing season, water the plant once the top inch of soil feels dry to the touch. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so ensure adequate drainage. In summer, you might need to increase watering frequency due to higher temperatures and faster evaporation. However, in the dormant or cooler months, water sparingly as the plant requires less moisture. Mulching can help retain soil moisture and keep root temperatures stable."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Malva neglecta grows best in full sun to partial shade. Ideally, it prefers at least 6 hours of direct sunlight daily, which promotes robust flowering and healthy growth. However, it can tolerate some shade, especially in hotter climates where midday sun can be intense. In shaded areas, the plant might exhibit less vibrant growth and fewer flowers. If growing indoors or in a sunny spot is not an option, ensure it receives at least bright, indirect light to thrive. Consider relocating the plant seasonally to adjust for varying light conditions."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Malva neglecta is not typically necessary for its health, but it can be done to improve its appearance or manage size. Deadhead spent flowers to encourage prolonged blooming and prevent self-seeding, which this plant does prolifically. In early spring, remove any damaged or dead stems to make way for new growth. If the plant becomes too leggy or overgrown, you can trim it back to maintain a desirable shape and encourage denser foliage. Use clean, sharp tools to make clean cuts and minimize stress on the plant."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"dwarf mallow","description":"Malva neglecta is an annual growing to 0.6 m (2ft). It is also known as common mallow in the United States and also buttonweed, cheeseplant, cheeseweed, dwarf mallow and roundleaf mallow. Although often considered a weed, this plant is often consumed as a food. This is especially true of the seeds, which contain 21% protein and 15.2% fat. The plant is an invasive species in the United States.","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Summer","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Eurasia"],"other_name":["dwarf mallow"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["October"],"scientific_name":["Malva neglecta"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":13498,"attracts":["Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Polygonum aviculare, commonly known as Knotgrass, is a resilient plant that doesn't require frequent watering once established. It prefers slightly dry soil conditions between watering sessions. Watering is generally necessary only during prolonged dry spells or drought conditions. Ensure that the soil has good drainage to prevent waterlogging, which can lead to root rot. During the initial stages of growth, regular watering will help the plant develop a healthy root system. As a rule of thumb, allow the top inch of the soil to dry out before re-watering."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Polygonum aviculare thrives in full sun to partial shade conditions. Full sunlight exposure helps promote robust growth and flowering. However, this plant is adaptable and can tolerate a range of light conditions, including partial shade. In shaded areas, it may become leggier and produce fewer flowers. For optimal health and best flowering results, it is recommended to provide at least 4 to 6 hours of direct sunlight per day. If grown indoors, place it near a bright window with ample natural light. Avoid overly shady areas to prevent weak growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Polygonum aviculare is straightforward and mainly involves removing dead or damaged stems to encourage vigorous growth and prevent diseases. This can be done annually, especially in late winter or early spring. Thinning the stems can also help promote better air circulation, reducing the risk of fungal infections. You can trim back aggressively growing stems to maintain the desired shape and prevent the plant from becoming too invasive. However, Knotgrass is a hardy plant and can tolerate heavy pruning if necessary."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Prostrate Knotweed","description":"Polygonum aviculare or common knotgrass is a plant related to buckwheat and dock. It is also called prostrate knotweed, birdweed, pigweed and lowgrass. It is an annual found in fields and wasteland, with white flowers from June to October. It is widespread across many countries in temperate regions, apparently native to Eurasia and North America, naturalized in temperate parts of the Southern Hemisphere.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Eurasia"],"other_name":["Prostrate Knotweed"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Polygonum aviculare"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

However, it is important to avoid overwatering, which can lead to root rot. During the winter months, reduce watering and let the soil dry slightly between waterings. It is ideal to water in the morning to allow excess moisture to evaporate throughout the day."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Scrophularia lanceolata thrives in full sun to partial shade. It prefers at least 4 to 6 hours of direct sunlight each day, especially in cooler climates. However, in regions with intense heat, some afternoon shade can prevent the leaves from scorching. If grown in too much shade, the plant may become leggy and produce fewer flowers. Therefore, a balance of morning sun and afternoon shade is ideal for optimal growth and flowering."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Scrophularia lanceolata is generally minimal but can be beneficial to maintain shape and promote bushier growth. During early spring, remove any dead or damaged stems to encourage healthy new growth. If the plant becomes too leggy or tall, you can trim back up to one-third of the plant's height, cutting just above a set of leaves to stimulate branching. After flowering, deadheading, or removing spent flowers, can help conserve the plant's energy and prolong the blooming period."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"lanceleaf figwort","description":"Scrophularia lanceolata is a species of flowering plant in the figwort family known by the common name lanceleaf figwort. It is native to North America, where it is known from western and eastern Canada and much of the United States except for the southeastern quadrant. It grows in many types of habitat, sometimes including disturbed areas such as roadsides. It is a perennial herb producing clusters of erect or spreading stems up to 1.5 meters long....","family":null,"flower_color":"Brown","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["lanceleaf figwort"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Scrophularia lanceolata"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":13101,"attracts":["Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Fraxinus anomala, commonly known as single-leaf ash, prefers a moderate watering regime. This plant is native to arid and semi-arid regions, making it quite drought-tolerant. It is important to allow the soil to dry out between waterings to prevent root rot, as excess moisture can harm the plant. During the growing season, aim to water deeply but infrequently, about once every two weeks. In winter, reduce watering significantly, only providing moisture if the soil becomes extremely dry. Always check the top 2-3 inches of soil for dryness before watering again."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Fraxinus anomala thrives in full sun to partial shade conditions. Ideally, it should receive at least six hours of direct sunlight each day to grow robustly. In full sun locations, the plant can develop a denser canopy and better overall form. However, it can also adapt to partial shade, although this may result in a sparser appearance. If planted in too much shade, its growth may be stunted, and it may become more susceptible to diseases. Ensuring adequate sunlight exposure is crucial to maintaining a healthy and vigorous Fraxinus anomala."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Fraxinus anomala should focus on maintaining its shape and removing any dead or diseased branches. The best time to prune is during late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Start by removing any crossed or inward-growing branches to improve air circulation and light penetration. If the plant is becoming too dense, thin out some of the older growth to encourage new development. It's advised to use clean, sharp tools to make precise cuts, which will help the plant heal quickly and reduce the risk of disease."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"single-leaf ash","description":"Fraxinus anomala is a species of ash tree known by the common name single-leaf ash. It is native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico, where it grows in a number of habitats including desert scrub and chaparral. It is unusual in the genus in that some (though not all) specimens have simple leaves instead of the pinnate leaves more characteristic of the group.","family":null,"flower_color":"Cream","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Autumn","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["United States","Mexico"],"other_name":["single-leaf ash"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Fraxinus anomala"],"soil":["Well-drained","Rocky"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

It should only be watered sparingly. Allow the soil to dry out completely between watering sessions, as over-watering can lead to root rot. During prolonged dry periods, especially in the summer, provide water once every two weeks. Ensure proper drainage to prevent waterlogging, as this plant does not tolerate standing water. During the winter, reduce watering significantly, especially if the plant is grown outdoors in regions that receive rainfall."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Cistus crispus thrives in full sun and requires at least six hours of direct sunlight each day to perform well. It can tolerate partial shade, but flowering might be reduced. Plant it in an area where it receives ample light throughout the day, as this enhances flowering and helps keep the plant healthy. A south or west-facing position is ideal in most regions. In areas with extremely hot summers, a bit of afternoon shade can help prevent potential leaf scorch, although the plant is generally very sun-resilient."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Cistus crispus is not strictly necessary, but it can help maintain shape and encourage new growth. It's best to prune right after the plant has finished flowering in late spring or early summer. Light pruning aids in creating a compact shape but avoid heavy pruning which can reduce flowering the following season."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"curly rockrose","description":"Cistus crispus is a shrubby species of flowering plant in the family Cistaceae , with pink to purple flowers, native to south-western Europe and western north Africa.","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Mediterranean Region"],"other_name":["curly rockrose"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Cistus crispus"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":12401,"attracts":["Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Dendrobium nobile orchids prefer a wet and dry cycle in watering. During spring and summer, when they are actively growing, water them once a week, ensuring that the potting medium is thoroughly soaked, and allow it to dry before watering again. In fall and winter, reduce watering to once every two weeks to promote blooming, while ensuring the medium does not completely dry out. Use distilled or rainwater at room temperature to avoid mineral buildup. Be cautious not to let the orchid sit in water as this can cause root rot."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Dendrobium nobile orchids require bright, indirect sunlight for optimal growth. Ideally, place them in a location where they receive about 50% shade, such as near an east or south-facing window with a sheer curtain. Direct sunlight, especially during midday, can scorch their leaves, while too little light can hinder flowering. If the leaves turn a deep green, the plant might be lacking enough light, whereas yellowing indicates too much. Adjust their position as needed to ensure they receive adequate light without damage."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Dendrobium nobile involves careful removal of dead or yellowing leaves and canes. Wait until after the flowering period has ended to prune, allowing the plant to absorb nutrients from older canes before cutting them. Use sterilized scissors to cut the canes close to their base. It's important not to cut off green or healthy canes as they can store nutrients and water, which are crucial for the orchid’s survival and future blooms. Remove any spent flowers to encourage the plant to focus energy on growth rather than seed production."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":null,"description":"The Noble Dendrobium, Dendrobium nobile, is a member of the family Orchidaceae. It has become a popular cultivated decorative house plant, because it produces colourful blooms in winter and spring, at a time when little else is in flower. It is also one of the 50 fundamental herbs used in traditional Chinese medicine, known as shí hú (Chinese: 石斛) or shí hú lán (Chinese: 石斛兰). Dendrobium nobile is one of the most widespread ornamental members of...","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Southeast Asia","Himalayas"],"other_name":null,"pest_susceptibility":["Spider mites","Aphids","Mealybugs"],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Dendrobium nobile"],"soil":["Well-drained","Bark mixture","Sphagnum moss"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

It's best to prune in early spring, just before the new growth appears, as this allows the fern to focus its energy on producing fresh fronds. Use clean, sharp scissors or pruning shears to cut off the old leaves at their base. Be careful not to damage new fronds emerging from the center of the plant. Regular removal of dead foliage throughout the growing season can also help prevent disease and improve air circulation around the plant."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"male fern","description":"Dryopteris filix-mas, the male fern, is a common fern of the temperate Northern Hemisphere, native to much of Europe, Asia, and North America. The plant is sometimes referred to in ancient literature as worm fern.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Europe","Asia","North America"],"other_name":["male fern"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot","Rust"],"propagation":["Spore Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Dryopteris filix-mas"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

When planting, ensure the site offers ample sunlight exposure throughout the day for optimal growth and blooming potential. Lack of sunlight can result in leggy growth and fewer blooms."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Penstemon cyananthus involves removing spent blooms to encourage continuous flowering and prevent the plant from becoming leggy. Deadheading can be done by cutting the flower stalks down to the main foliage once the blooms have faded. After the flowering season is over, you can tidy up the plant by trimming back any dead or damaged stems in late fall or early spring. This not only helps maintain the plant's shape but also encourages healthy growth. Reduce watering slightly as the plant matures, especially if there's significant rainfall, to avoid oversaturation."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Coriandrum sativum thrives in full sun conditions but can also tolerate partial shade, especially in hot climates where intense afternoon sun might cause it to bolt prematurely. Aim for at least 4-6 hours of direct sunlight per day for optimal growth. In hotter regions, providing some afternoon shade can help prolong the growing period by delaying bolting. If growing indoors, place the plant near a south-facing window where it can receive ample sunlight. A consistent light source will ensure the plant grows healthy and robust with abundant foliage."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning or harvesting Coriandrum sativum involves regularly cutting the leaves to encourage bushier growth and prevent bolting, which is premature flowering that ends leaf production. Start harvesting when the plants are around 4-6 inches tall, pinching or cutting the outer leaves first, allowing the center to continue growing. Remove any flower buds as they appear to extend the leaf-producing period. Consistent pruning or harvesting keeps the plant lush and productive, increasing the overall yield and prolonging its life cycle. If the intention is to harvest seeds, allow the flower heads to mature."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"coriander","description":"Coriander (UK: /ˌkɒrɪˈændər/; US: /ˈkɔːriˌændər/ or /ˌkɔːriˈændər/; Coriandrum sativum), also known as cilantro (/sɪˈlɑːntroʊ/) or Chinese parsley, is an annual herb in the family Apiaceae. Regular pruning is not necessary, but occasional cleaning will improve airflow and light penetration, helping to prevent pest issues and promote healthy growth."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Abrams' Liveforever","description":"Dudleya abramsii is a succulent plant known by the common name Abrams' liveforever. It is native to California and northern Baja California, where it grows in rocky areas in a number of habitat types. Ensure the soil is kept moist but not waterlogged, as too much water can lead to bulb rot. It’s best to water deeply, allowing the top inch of soil to dry out between waterings. Decrease watering once the flowering period ends and the leaves begin to yellow, eventually letting the soil dry out completely once the plant is dormant. This helps in preventing rot over the winter period when the plant is not actively growing. Adequate drainage is crucial for their healthy growth."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Gladiolus italicus thrives in full sunlight, requiring at least six hours of direct sunlight each day for optimal growth and flowering. They flourish best in bright, sunny locations that provide consistent warmth throughout the day. Planting them in areas with light afternoon shade can help in regions with extremely hot and dry climates. Insufficient sunlight can result in weak, spindly plants with reduced flowering. Therefore, finding a sunny spot or ensuring they receive ample sunlight is essential for vibrant blooms and healthy foliage development."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Gladiolus italicus involves removing spent flowers to encourage continual blooming and prevent seed formation, which diverts energy from bulb growth. Once flowering is complete, allow the leaves to die back naturally as they provide nutrients to the bulbs for the next growing season. Only cut back the foliage after it has fully yellowed and died back at the end of the growing season. This process not only aids in pest and disease prevention but also ensures that the plant's energy is reserved for producing strong blooms in the following year."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Field Gladiolus","description":"Gladiolus italicus is a species of gladiolus known by the common names Italian gladiolus, field gladiolus, and common sword-lily.","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Mediterranean Europe","Western Asia"],"other_name":["Field Gladiolus"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot","Stem borer insects"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["November"],"scientific_name":["Gladiolus italicus"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

As the tree matures, reduce the frequency of watering, gradually allowing the top inch of soil to dry out between sessions. In arid climates, supplemental watering during prolonged dry spells helps maintain health but avoid overwatering to prevent root rot. Mulching around the base conserves moisture and regulates soil temperature."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Quercus tomentella thrives in full sun to partial shade environments. Ideally, provide it with at least six hours of direct sunlight daily, ensuring robust growth and overall health. In areas with intense, prolonged sunlight, some afternoon shade helps protect the tree from leaf scorch. While the plant can tolerate shade to some extent, lack of adequate sunlight may lead to sparse foliage and reduced vigor. If planted in dense shade conditions, monitoring for signs of stress, such as leggy growth or reduced leaf size, is important for optimal care."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Quercus tomentella is best done during its dormant season in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Focus on removing dead, damaged, or crossing branches to improve the tree’s structure and air circulation, which helps prevent disease. Younger trees benefit from formative pruning to establish a strong framework of branches. Avoid heavy pruning and topping, as it stresses the tree, leading to poor health or growth. Use clean, sharp tools to make precise cuts, and for larger branches, employ the three-cut method to prevent bark tearing."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"island oak","description":"Quercus tomentella, the island oak, island live oak, or Channel Island oak, is an oak in the section Protobalanus. During its first year, regular watering helps establish a strong root system, but afterwards, it can survive with minimal water. Be cautious of waterlogged soil, as this can lead to root rot. Ensure the plant is placed in a spot that receives ample natural light to support its growth and overall health. Proper sun exposure encourages vibrant foliage and flowering."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Arctostaphylos crustacea should be done lightly and sparingly, primarily for maintaining shape and removing dead or diseased branches. The best time to prune is late winter to early spring before new growth starts. It's important to avoid cutting into older wood, as this can harm the plant; instead, focus on new growth. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":12501,"attracts":["Birds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Metasequoia glyptostroboides, commonly known as the dawn redwood, requires consistently moist soil to thrive, especially during its growing season in the spring and summer. It does best in moist, well-drained soil, and regular watering is essential if rain is scarce. However, it's important not to let the soil become waterlogged, as this can lead to root rot. During the dormant winter months, reduce watering frequency, but do not let the soil dry out completely. A consistent watering schedule ensures healthy growth and development for this deciduous conifer."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"The dawn redwood thrives in full sun conditions, which means it requires at least six hours of direct sunlight each day. This amount of sunlight supports its vigorous growth and vibrant foliage. Although it can tolerate partial shade, full sun is optimal for it to reach its potential height and display its beautiful deciduous characteristics. In a location with plentiful sunlight, the tree will develop strong branches and its distinctive, feathery green needles, which turn a lovely reddish-brown in autumn, creating a striking seasonal display."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Metasequoia glyptostroboides is generally straightforward due to its naturally graceful shape. It is best pruned when the tree is dormant, in late winter or early spring, before new growth begins. Remove dead, damaged, or diseased branches to maintain the tree's health. However, be cautious of overwatering, as it can lead to root rot. The plant can tolerate occasional flooding but prefers consistent moisture levels. This species can endure heavy pruning, but it's often best to do minimal pruning to preserve its natural form unless space constraints require size control. Avoid pruning during the colder months as the plant may be more susceptible to stress during this time."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Shrubby Tiquilia","description":"Tiquilia canescens, the woody crinklemat or shrubby tiquilia, is a perennial, shrub in mid- to lower-elevation desert regions in the Boraginaceae family - Borage or the Forget-me-nots. Adjust placement as necessary to avoid excessive sun exposure in very hot climates."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Scutellaria mexicana involves removing dead or damaged stems and leaves to encourage healthier growth. It is best to prune in the early spring before the plant begins its active growth period. Trim back leggy or overgrown stems to promote a more compact and dense growth habit. Pinch back the tips of new growth during the growing season to encourage branching and fuller foliage. Deadhead spent flowers regularly to prolong blooming. Avoid heavy pruning late in the season as it may reduce the plant's ability to survive any dormant period."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Paperbag Bush","description":"Scutellaria mexicana, commonly known by variants on bladder sage or paperbag bush, is a shrub of the mint family Lamiaceae distinctive for its calyx lobes that develop into small bag- or bladder-like shells around the fruits.","family":null,"flower_color":"Blue","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Mexico","Southwestern United States"],"other_name":["Paperbag Bush"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Scutellaria mexicana"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14605,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Pandanus amaryllifolius, commonly known as pandan, requires regular watering to keep the soil consistently moist. Overwatering should be avoided as it can lead to root rot, characterized by yellowing leaves and mushy roots. Well-draining soil is crucial to prevent water from accumulating in the pot. During winter, reduce the frequency of watering, ensuring that the plant does not dry out completely while adapting to indoor conditions."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Pandanus amaryllifolius thrives in a position where it receives bright, indirect light. It can tolerate some direct sunlight, especially morning sun, but exposure to intense midday or afternoon sun may scorch its leaves. Ideally, place the plant near a window where it can receive filtered sunlight, or provide partial shade if it is outdoors. If growing indoors, especially away from windows, consider supplementing with artificial grow lights. The plant is versatile in its sun needs but consistently performs best with plenty of indirect light and good air circulation."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning should be done to maintain the shape of Pandanus amaryllifolius and to remove any dead or damaged leaves. Avoid overhead watering, as wet leaves can lead to rot; instead, water at the base of the plant. Inadequate light can cause the plant to become leggy, while too much can lead to sunburn."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Dudleya attenuata is minimal, focusing primarily on maintaining plant health and appearance. Remove any dead or damaged leaves by gently pulling them away from the base, which helps prevent pest infestations and disease. Avoid cutting healthy leaves, as this can damage the plant. Pruning is best done during the plant’s dormant period in the summer, and always use clean, sharp tools to make clean cuts, minimizing damage to the fleshy leaves. Additionally, trim flower stalks after blooming to redirect energy back to the plant."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Tapertip Liveforever","description":"Dudleya attenuata, common names including Orcutt's live-forever and Tapertip live-forever, is plant species native to California and to Baja California.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["California","Baja California"],"other_name":["Tapertip Liveforever"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Dudleya attenuata"],"soil":["Well-drained","Gravelly","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

It prefers to dry out slightly between waterings. Check the top inch of the soil and water if it feels dry to the touch. Overwatering should be avoided to prevent root rot. The plant is relatively drought-tolerant, so it's better to underwater than overwater. During the growing season, spring and summer, it may require more frequent watering than in the cooler months. Ensure the pot has good drainage to allow excess water to escape."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Aspidistra elatior thrives in low to moderate light conditions, making it an ideal choice for shaded areas of your home. It can also tolerate low light and indirect sunlight but avoids direct sun exposure to prevent leaf scorch. This plant is highly adaptable to varying light conditions, but more indirect light can encourage better growth. If placed in a well-lit room, keep it away from direct sunlight by positioning it a few feet from windows or using sheer curtains to diffuse the light. Adaptability to low light levels is one of its qualities, making it perfect for rooms with minimal natural light."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Aspidistra elatior generally involves trimming away any dead or damaged leaves to maintain the plant's appearance and health. This can be done year-round as necessary. Remove leaves by cutting them at the base with clean, sharp scissors or pruning shears. This helps prevent the potential spread of disease. Occasionally, you may need to divide the plant if it becomes too large for its pot. This is best done during repotting in spring. Regularly cleaning the leaves can help keep the plant looking its best as it removes dust and supports better photosynthesis."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"cast-iron plant","description":"Aspidistra elatior, the cast-iron-plant or bar room plant, also known in Japanese as haran or baran (葉蘭) is a species of flowering plant in the family Asparagaceae, native to Japan and Taiwan. Tolerant of neglect, it is widely cultivated as a houseplant, but can also be grown outside in shade where temperatures remain above −5 °C (23 °F).","family":null,"flower_color":"Purple","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Japan","China"],"other_name":["cast-iron plant"],"pest_susceptibility":["Spider mites"],"propagation":["Division"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Aspidistra elatior"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Afternoon"}}

You can thin the inner branches to improve air circulation and light penetration, which helps discourage diseases. Regular light pruning is recommended to keep the tree looking tidy and encourage a strong structure, but avoid heavy pruning in one go, as it can stress the plant. Ensure using clean, sharp tools and cut branches at their base to promote healthy regrowth."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"african sumac","description":"Searsia lancea commonly known as karee, \"karree\" (Afrikaans), \"hlokoshiyne\" (isiZulu), \"umhlakotshane\" (amaXhosa), or \"mokalaabata\" (Northern Sotho), is an evergreen, frost hardy, drought resistant tree, which can reach up to 8 metres in height with a 5 metre spread. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14208,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Bjerkandera adusta is not a traditional houseplant but a type of wood-decay fungus; thus, it doesn't require typical watering like plants. Instead, if you are cultivating it for study or ecological restoration purposes, it thrives on moisture present in decaying wood. Ensure that the wood substrate it grows on remains moist but not waterlogged. If you're attempting to cultivate it indoors, periodically mist the wood surface to maintain adequate humidity levels. Avoid standing water as this can lead to unfavorable conditions for fungal growth."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Bjerkandera adusta, being a fungus, doesn't require sunlight for growth as it doesn't perform photosynthesis. It primarily thrives in shady, moist environments, often found in forest floors under tree canopies. When cultivating or observing it, provide an environment that mimics its natural habitat which would be low-light or indirect light conditions. Excessive direct sunlight could dehydrate its environment, so maintaining shaded and humid conditions is ideal for its growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is not applicable for Bjerkandera adusta as it is a fungus and not a plant with foliage or branches. Instead, manage the growth environment by ensuring ample decayed wood material for it to colonize. Removing older, decayed portions of the fungus might be pertinent if foraging or studying different stages of decay. This process helps maintain space and resources for new growth but actual pruning, as understood with plants, is not relevant to fungal care."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Smoky polypore","description":"Bjerkandera adusta, commonly known as the smoky polypore or smoky bracket, is a species of fungus in the family Meruliaceae. It is important to keep the soil consistently moist but not waterlogged. Water the plant thoroughly once or twice a week, allowing the top inch of soil to dry out between waterings. During periods of active growth, such as spring and summer, goldenrod may require more frequent watering. Reduce the frequency in winter when the plant's growth slows down. Well-drained soil is crucial to prevent root rot, so ensure the plant is not sitting in water."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Solidago virgaurea flourishes in full sun conditions, requiring at least six hours of direct sunlight per day to bloom vigorously. If grown in a region with very hot summers, offering some afternoon shade can prevent leaf scorch. Ensuring sufficient sunlight exposure is key for the plant to maintain its health and produce the iconic bright yellow flowers characteristic of goldenrod."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Solidago virgaurea helps control its growth and encourages a bushier plant. The best time to prune is in early spring before new growth begins, or in autumn after flowering. Remove any dead, damaged, or diseased stems at the base. To maintain shape and prevent the plant from becoming too leggy, you can cut back about one-third of the stems. Deadheading spent flowers throughout the blooming season can prolong flowering and prevent the plant from self-seeding excessively. Regular pruning helps manage its size and promotes healthier growth."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"European goldenrod","description":"Solidago virgaurea (European goldenrod or woundwort) is an herbaceous perennial plant of the family Asteraceae. It is grown as a garden flower with many different cultivars. The best time to prune is immediately after flowering in late spring or early summer. Use sharp, clean pruning shears to trim back any dead or straggly branches, cutting just above a pair of healthy leaves. Avoid cutting into the old wood as new growth from old wood can be minimal. Lightly shaping the plant helps maintain its aesthetic appeal and promotes a denser growth habit for a fuller appearance in the following season."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Tree heath","description":"Erica arborea (tree heath) is a species of flowering plant (angiosperms) in the heather family, Ericaceae. There are disjunct populations in Africa including the Ethiopian Highlands, the mountains of Ruwenzori and the Cameroon Mountains. In Africa it is normally referred to as giant heather. It is native to the maquis shrublands surrounding the Mediterranean Basin north to Bulgaria and west to Portugal and the Canary and Madeira Islands. Naturalised populations occur in south-eastern Australia.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Europe","Africa"],"other_name":["Tree heath"],"pest_susceptibility":["Mildew"],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Erica arborea"],"soil":["Acidic","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

It does not require watering in the traditional sense, but it does need stable water levels and good water quality. Ensure that the tank or body of water where it is planted maintains a pH between 6.5 and 8.0, as well as moderate hardness. Regular water changes, every one to two weeks, will help keep the water clean. When adding water, ensure it is dechlorinated and at a temperature similar to the existing water to prevent shocking the plant."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Vallisneria americana prefers moderate to high lighting conditions to thrive, ideally receiving about 8 to 12 hours of light each day. It can adapt to various light levels, but optimal growth is seen with sufficient light. In an aquarium setting, using full-spectrum LED or fluorescent lights can simulate the natural sunlight required by this plant. Be cautious with too much light as it can lead to algae growth. In an outdoor pond, partial sunlight is enough, and some shading during the hottest part of the day can prevent overheating and algae issues."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Vallisneria americana is essential to prevent it from taking over the aquatic environment, as it can grow quite large. Use scissors to trim the leaves just above the substrate to maintain the desired height. Remove any damaged, brown, or dying leaves to promote healthy growth and water circulation. If the plant is propagating too rapidly, some of the runners can be trimmed back or removed entirely. Regular pruning helps prevent the plant from overshadowing other aquarium species and encourages a tidier appearance."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"American eelgrass","description":"Vallisneria americana, commonly called wild celery, water-celery, tape grass, or eelgrass, is a plant in the family Hydrocharitaceae, the \"tape-grasses\". However, once established, these trees are relatively drought-tolerant and can survive with natural rainfall in most climates. It's essential to ensure that the soil does not become waterlogged, as the European ash prefers well-drained soil. During prolonged dry spells, occasional deep watering is beneficial. Overwatering should be avoided to prevent root rot, especially in heavy clay soils."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Fraxinus excelsior thrives best in full sun conditions but can also tolerate partial shade. Providing ample sunlight supports robust growth, better leaf production, and a more resilient structure. However, young trees may benefit from some shade, as excessive heat can damage tender foliage during their initial growth stages."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Fraxinus excelsior is ideally carried out during late winter or early spring when the tree is dormant. The primary aim of pruning should be to remove any dead, diseased, or damaged branches, which helps to promote healthy growth and improve air circulation within the tree. Additionally, removing any crossing branches that could lead to crowding or rubbing against each other is essential. It's important to avoid heavy pruning, as this can stress the tree. Light, regular pruning encourages a strong structure and enhances the tree's natural shape."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"European ash","description":"Fraxinus excelsior, known as the ash, or European ash or common ash to distinguish it from other types of ash, is a flowering plant species in the olive family Oleaceae. The species is widely cultivated and reportedly naturalised in New Zealand and in scattered locales in the United States and Canada.","family":null,"flower_color":"Green","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Green\"]","growth_rate":"High","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Europe","Western Asia"],"other_name":["European ash"],"pest_susceptibility":["Ash dieback","Emerald ash borer"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Fraxinus excelsior"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15006,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Limodorum abortivum, commonly known as violet limodore, is a mycoheterotrophic orchid that largely relies on its symbiotic relationship with fungi for nutrients. In cultivation, it’s important not to overwater. It should be watered when the surrounding soil appears very dry, especially during its active growth period in spring. In general, allow for good drainage to prevent water stagnation."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Limodorum abortivum thrives in dappled to partial shade, similar to the forest understorey environments where it is naturally found. Direct, strong sunlight can be harmful and should be avoided; instead, it should be placed where it will receive filtered light, such as under trees or in a lightly shaded area with indirect sunlight. This plant benefits from environments that mimic its natural habitat – shaded yet warm locations. Ideal sunlight exposure should also maintain humidity and avoid overly dry conditions, which can be challenging for this orchid to thrive in."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Limodorum abortivum is not typically required as it is an orchid with a specific life cycle, characterized by a lack of leaves and minimal aboveground growth. If it is grown in an area with more sun, ensure it has consistent moisture to cope with the increased evaporation and heat stress."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Amphicarpaea bracteata is generally minimal, as it is a trailing plant that can spread naturally in its habitat. This pruning will help the plant maintain its shape and direct more energy to producing flowers and seeds."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"American hog-peanut","description":"Amphicarpaea bracteata (hog-peanut or ground bean) is an annual to perennial vine in the legume family, native to woodland, thickets, and moist slopes in eastern North America.","family":null,"flower_color":"Purple","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Autumn","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["American hog-peanut"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot","Mildew"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Amphicarpaea bracteata"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":13601,"attracts":["Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Water Secale cereale (rye) regularly during its growth phase to maintain moist soil but ensure good drainage to avoid water-logging. Rye is moderately drought-tolerant once established, yet consistent watering will significantly improve yields and growth. It's advisable to water deeply at less frequent intervals to encourage deeper root growth, particularly during periods of drought or extreme heat. Overwatering should be avoided as it can lead to fungal diseases. Hence, monitoring the soil’s moisture by finger testing a few inches below the surface can help determine the appropriate watering schedule."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Secale cereale (rye) thrives in full sun conditions, requiring at least six to eight hours of sunlight daily. This exposure to sunlight promotes healthy growth and grain production. Rye is also adaptable to partial shade but the yield and growth might not be as robust compared to when grown in full sun. Therefore, situating rye in areas with maximum exposure ensures optimal photosynthesis and energy production. It is suitable for a range of climates but planting in well-lit, open spaces will enhance vigor and resilience. Rye is typically planted in fall or spring, capitalizing on full sunlight during growth seasons."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is not typically necessary for Secale cereale (rye) as it is primarily grown as a cereal grain or cover crop. However, in a garden setting where aesthetic appeal is important, regular trimming of stray or yellowing leaves may be done. If grown for grain, allow the plant to mature and only cut down the stalks after seed heads have formed and the plant starts drying. This typically occurs late in the growing season. For cover cropping, mow or chop the plant mass prior to flowering to prevent seed set and to optimize its organic matter contribution to the soil."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"rye","description":"Rye (Secale cereale) is a grass grown extensively as a grain, a cover crop and a forage crop. It is a member of the wheat tribe (Triticeae) and is closely related to barley (genus Hordeum) and wheat (Triticum). Rye grain is used for flour, rye bread, rye beer, crisp bread, some whiskeys, some vodkas, and animal fodder. It can also be eaten whole, either as boiled rye berries or by being rolled, similar to rolled oats.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Autumn","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Turkey","Iran"],"other_name":["rye"],"pest_susceptibility":["Leaf rust","Stem rust"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["July"],"scientific_name":["Secale cereale"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Ensure the soil remains consistently moist, ideally mimicking its natural environment by using acidic, poorly-drained soil. Water frequently, especially during dry spells or if grown in containers. Avoid letting the plant dry out completely, as this can lead to wilting or damage to its delicate root system. It's crucial to keep the soil damp, not waterlogged, so provide good drainage even as you maintain a high level of moisture. Using rainwater is preferred over tap water, which can alter the soil's pH."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Narthecium ossifragum prefers full sunlight but can tolerate partial shade, especially in hotter climates where too much sun might scorch the leaves. Ideally, give it five to six hours of direct sunlight each day to encourage robust growth and flowering. When planted in a bog garden or alongside ponds, ensure it has unobstructed access to the sun. Partial shade in the afternoon can help prevent leaf burn during summer's intensity. While adaptable, too much shade can reduce flowering and lead to leggy growth, so position it well within your garden's sunnier aspects."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Narthecium ossifragum is minimal, focusing mainly on removing spent flower spikes after they have finished blooming. This encourages the plant to divert its energy back into the roots and overall growth. Cut back the flower stalks to the base, using clean, sharp scissors or pruners to prevent disease spread. Additionally, remove any dead or damaged leaves as they appear, to maintain a tidy appearance and ensure the plant's longevity. This plant will typically need little other intervention throughout its growing season, thriving with basic maintenance."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"bog asphodel","description":"Narthecium ossifragum, commonly known as bog asphodel, Lancashire asphodel or bastard asphodel, is a plant of Western Europe, found on wet, boggy moorlands up to about 1000 m in elevation. It produces spikes of bright yellow flowers in summer. The bright orange fruits have been used as a colourant to replace saffron by Shetland Islanders. Despite the plant's English name, it is not particularly closely related to the true asphodels.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Europe","North Africa"],"other_name":["bog asphodel"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Narthecium ossifragum"],"soil":["Acidic","Well-drained","Moist"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

A layer of organic mulch can help retain soil moisture and keep the roots cool. In extremely hot climates, be mindful to increase watering frequency to ensure the soil remains adequately moist. It can tolerate morning sun, but too much direct sunlight, especially in hot climates, can scorch the foliage. An ideal location would be a shaded spot that receives dappled sunlight or is protected by taller trees and shrubs. While it can handle some sunlight, ensuring adequate shade will help maintain vibrant, healthy foliage and support the plant’s growth, as it naturally grows in forested or woodland areas. A location with shelter from harsh afternoon rays is beneficial to avoid stress and leaf damage."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Actaea racemosa is mainly done to maintain its shape and encourage healthy growth. Deadheading spent flowers can promote better appearance and may prevent self-seeding. At the end of the growing season, usually in late autumn, you can cut back the entire plant to the ground once the foliage has died back. This cleanup helps prevent overwintering pests or diseases. Always use sharp, sterilized pruning tools to make clean cuts and avoid damage to the plant. Pruning is generally minimal but essential for a tidy garden appearance and healthy plant growth."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"black cohosh","description":"Actaea racemosa (black cohosh, black bugbane, black snakeroot, fairy candle; syn. Cimicifuga racemosa) is a species of flowering plant of the family Ranunculaceae. Too much direct sunlight can cause the foliage to scorch, whereas insufficient light can lead to weak and elongated growth. Indoors, place the plant near a south or east-facing window for optimal light exposure."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Dudleya pulverulenta is minimal. Remove dead or dried leaves from the plant by gently twisting them off at the base to maintain health and aesthetics. This can be done throughout the year as needed. It is important to handle the plant carefully as the leaves are brittle."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Chalk Dudleya","description":"Dudleya pulverulenta is a succulent plant known by the common names chalk lettuce, chalk dudleya, and chalk liveforever.","family":null,"flower_color":"Red","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Gray-green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["United States","Mexico"],"other_name":["Chalk Dudleya"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Leaf cuttings","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["June"],"scientific_name":["Dudleya pulverulenta"],"soil":["Well-drained","Rocky","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

New plants should be watered lightly each day during their first week, and gradually reduced to once or twice a week as the plant establishes itself. Rosa rugosa is quite drought-tolerant once mature, but during hot summer months, it may benefit from deeper watering every two weeks to promote healthy blooms. Always ensure the soil has good drainage to prevent root rot, avoiding waterlogging while keeping the soil moist, especially in the growing season from spring to early fall."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Rosa rugosa thrives in full sunlight, needing at least six hours of direct sunlight each day to produce its abundant blooms. While it can tolerate partial shade, full sun exposure ensures the best flowering and plant health. In areas with intense summer heat, a spot with afternoon shade can be helpful, but morning sun is crucial for the plant to dry off and reduce disease risk. For optimum growth, choose a location that receives consistent sun exposure throughout the day, encouraging lush foliage and a profusion of flowers."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Rosa rugosa is essential for maintaining its shape and encouraging healthy growth. The best time to prune is in late winter or early spring before new growth starts. Begin by removing any dead, damaged, or diseased wood. Thin out overcrowded stems to improve air circulation, which reduces the risk of fungal diseases. Aim to keep the center of the bush open. Trim back the main stems by about a third to stimulate more robust flowering. After blooming, deadhead spent flowers to promote continuous blooming throughout the season."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"rugosa rose","description":"Rosa rugosa (rugosa rose, beach rose, Japanese rose, or Ramanas rose) is a species of rose native to eastern Asia, in northeastern China, Japan, Korea and southeastern Siberia, where it grows on the coast, often on sand dunes. It should not be confused with Rosa multiflora, which is also known as \"Japanese rose\". The Latin word \"rugosa\" means \"wrinkled.\"","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Red\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Eastern Asia"],"other_name":["rugosa rose"],"pest_susceptibility":["Mildew","Black spot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Rosa rugosa"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

If natural light is insufficient, fluorescent grow lights can be a suitable alternative. While Anthuriums can tolerate lower light levels, this may result in reduced flowering. Rotate the plant occasionally to ensure balanced growth and prevent it from leaning towards the light source. Avoid placing it in areas with direct exposure to harsh midday sun rays."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning an Anthurium andraeanum involves removing dead or yellowing leaves to maintain health and aesthetics. Ensure that the light intensity and duration mimic natural conditions, as too little light can stunt its growth while too much can lead to water temperature increases that might be harmful."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Potamogeton crispus is important to prevent it from becoming invasive in your pond or aquarium. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14409,"attracts":["Butterflies","Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Antennaria plantaginifolia, commonly known as Pussytoes, is a drought-tolerant plant that requires minimal watering. Once established, it will thrive with rainfall alone. During dry spells, it’s advisable to water this plant every 2-3 weeks to maintain its health. Ensure the soil is well-drained, as overwatering can lead to root rot. The plant prefers having its roots kept fairly dry, so always let the soil dry out completely between watering sessions. Avoid waterlogged conditions, and watering at the base of the plant is recommended to prevent moisture on the foliage."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Antennaria plantaginifolia thrives in full sun to partial shade. It grows best when exposed to at least 6 hours of direct sunlight per day. In regions with extremely hot climates, some afternoon shade can be beneficial to prevent scorching. If grown in too much shade, the plant may become leggy and produce fewer flowers. Full sun exposure encourages dense foliage and a robust display of its characteristic, fuzzy flower heads. Ensure it gets adequate sunlight to support its growth and overall health, and monitor the plant for signs of either too much direct sun or insufficient light."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Antennaria plantaginifolia is generally straightforward. Remove any dead or damaged leaves to keep the plant tidy and healthy. This can be done throughout the growing season as needed. After the plant blooms, you can trim back the flowering stems to encourage bushier growth and prevent self-seeding if that is not desired. However, be cautious not to cut into the basal rosette of leaves, as this can damage the plant's growth. Pruning also helps to maintain the plant’s neat, ground-covering habit and encourages a more compact form."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"plantain-leaved pussytoes","description":"Antennaria plantaginifolia (known by the common names plantain leaf pussytoes and woman's tobacco) is a perennial forb native to the eastern North America, that produces cream colored composite flowers in spring.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["plantain-leaved pussytoes"],"pest_susceptibility":["Mildew"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["June"],"scientific_name":["Antennaria plantaginifolia"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

This should be done during or after the blooming period. Deadheading the spent flowers can prevent the plant from going to seed prematurely and will encourage more blooms. No major structural pruning is necessary, but you can trim back the plant in early spring to shape it and remove any dead or damaged foliage from the winter to make room for fresh growth to emerge."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Common Sea-lavender","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Blue","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Europe","North Africa"],"other_name":["Common Sea-lavender"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["October"],"scientific_name":["Limonium vulgare"],"soil":["Sandy","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Gently pull away brown or shriveled leaves at the base of the plant to allow room for new growth and to maintain a tidy appearance. Adequate sunlight ensures robust flower development and overall vitality of the plants."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Tulipa gesneriana mainly involves deadheading and cutting back the foliage. After the tulip blooms have faded, remove the spent flowers promptly to prevent the plant from directing energy into seed production. However, leave the foliage intact until it turns yellow and dies back naturally, as this process allows the bulb to store enough energy for the following year's growth. Once the leaves have fully wilted and yellowed, you can cut them down to the base. This ensures that the bulbs remain healthy and vigorous for future blooming seasons."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Garden Tulip","description":"Tulipa gesneriana, the Didier's tulip or garden tulip, is a species of plant in the lily family, cultivated as an ornamental in many countries because of its large, showy flowers. Most of the cultivars of tulip are derived from Tulipa gesneriana. Avoid planting in full sun to reduce the risk of plant stress and dehydration."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Mitchella repens is minimal, as it is a low-growing, creeping plant that naturally maintains a tidy appearance. During late winter or early spring, before new growth begins, gently trim any overly long stems to encourage bushier growth. Remove any dead, damaged, or diseased foliage and stems as they appear throughout the year to maintain plant health. By pruning selectively and sparingly, you encourage the plant to spread and cover ground more evenly, enhancing its decorative appeal in woodland gardens and as a ground cover. Once established, the tree is more drought tolerant but will benefit from deep, infrequent watering to encourage deep root growth. It is important to ensure that the soil has good drainage to prevent root rot. While it can tolerate partial shade, excessive shading can lead to lanky growth and reduced vigor. Generally, a sunnier location encourages a more robust structure and enhances the tree's aesthetic appeal. If planted in a predominantly shaded area, monitor for potential growth issues and consider strategic pruning to enhance light exposure."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Zelkova serrata should be performed primarily during late winter, before the spring growth begins. This timing helps minimize sap loss and encourages a good shape. Start by removing any dead, diseased, or crossing branches to promote healthy growth. You can also lightly shape the tree to maintain its natural vase-like form, which is characteristic of the species. Avoid heavy pruning as it can stress the tree. Regularly thin out crowded branches to improve air circulation and light penetration throughout the tree canopy. This also reduces the risk of disease."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Japanese zelkova","description":"Zelkova serrata (Japanese zelkova, Japanese elm or keyaki; Japanese: 欅 (ケヤキ) keyaki /槻 (ツキ) tsuki; Chinese: 榉树/櫸樹 jǔshù; Korean: 느티나무 neutinamu) is a species of the genus Zelkova native to Japan, Korea, eastern China and Taiwan. It is often grown as an ornamental tree, and used in bonsai. During its growing season, typically spring and summer, water it regularly but ensure that the soil has good drainage to prevent waterlogging. In particularly dry periods, increase the frequency of watering to maintain soil moisture, but avoid leaving the plant in standing water. Reduce watering in the fall and winter months when the plant is dormant, allowing the soil to dry out slightly between waterings as excessive moisture during dormancy can lead to root rot."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Thermopsis montana thrives in full sun to partial shade. Ideally, this plant should receive at least six hours of direct sunlight each day to promote vigorous growth and produce its characteristic yellow flowers. While it can tolerate some shade, insufficient sunlight might result in reduced blooming and a leggier growth habit. In regions with extremely hot summers, partial shade during the afternoon can help prevent leaf scorch and stress from excessive heat. Cut back spent flower stalks after blooming to encourage new growth and prevent the plant from becoming leggy. If the plant becomes too large for its space, it can be divided in the spring to both propagate new plants and manage its size. Be cautious when handling the plant, as its hairy stems can cause skin irritation for sensitive individuals."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Mountain goldenbean","description":"Thermopsis montana, the false lupin, mountain goldenbanner, golden pea, mountain thermopsis, or revonpapu, is a plant species which is native of the western United States. Ensure good drainage to prevent root rot, but do not let the soil dry out completely. During dry spells, especially in hot weather, more frequent watering is necessary to maintain soil moisture. Mulching can help conserve moisture levels, contributing to the overall health of the plant."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Packera aurea thrives in full to partial shade. It naturally grows in woodland and forested areas, where it receives indirect sunlight. Ideally, it should be placed in an area that gets morning sun with dappled or light shade in the afternoon. It can tolerate more sun if kept adequately moist. However, too much direct sunlight, especially in hot climates, can lead to leaf scorch and stress. Ensuring it has some protection from harsh afternoon sun will help maintain its vibrant foliage and floral display."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Packera aurea generally involves removing spent flowers and dead or damaged foliage. Deadheading the blooms after they fade can prolong the flowering period and prevent unwanted self-seeding. In late fall or early spring, consider cutting back the plant to encourage healthy new growth. This plant does not require extensive pruning; just occasional tidying up to manage its appearance and health. Avoid cutting it back too harshly as the foliage is also part of its ornamental appeal."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"golden ragwort","description":"Packera aurea (formerly Senecio aureus), commonly known as golden ragwort or simply ragwort, is a perennial flower in the family Asteraceae. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14809,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Paederia foetida prefers moderate watering, meaning it thrives best in consistently moist soil. However, ensure that the soil is well-drained to prevent waterlogging, which can cause root rot. During the active growing season in spring and summer, water the plant regularly, allowing the top inch of soil to dry out between waterings. In fall and winter, reduce watering frequency as the plant's growth rate slows down. The plant can tolerate temporary drought but maintaining balanced moisture encourages robust growth and flowering. Consider using rainwater if possible, as this reduces the exposure to hard water minerals."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Paederia foetida is adaptable to various light conditions but grows best in full sun to partial shade. Ideally, the plant should receive at least 4-6 hours of sunlight daily to maintain its health and vigor. In its natural habitat, it often grows in open areas where it receives ample sunlight, which promotes flowering and the production of vibrant foliage. However, it can tolerate some shade as well, though excessive shade might reduce flowering and lead to a leggy appearance. If grown indoors or in shaded areas, ensure it receives bright, indirect light for optimal growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Paederia foetida involves removing dead, damaged, or diseased stems to promote healthy growth and control its vigorous nature. It is recommended to prune the plant in late winter or early spring before new growth starts. You can also prune throughout the growing season to manage its size and shape, especially if it becomes too dense or starts invading unwanted areas. Be careful when pruning as the crushed leaves or stems emit a strong, pungent odor. Always use clean, sharp pruning tools to make cuts above a leaf node to encourage new growth."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"skunk vine","description":"Paederia foetida is a species of plant, with common names that are variations of skunkvine, stinkvine, or Chinese fever vine. Pruning should be done with care, using gloves to avoid injury from the plant’s sharp spines."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Spiniest thistle","description":"Cirsium spinosissimum , common name Spiniest Thistle, is a European species of thistle which grows in dry rocky areas. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15506,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Laricifomes officinalis, also known as agarikon, is a wood-decaying fungus primarily found on living or dead conifer trees. It requires high humidity, similar to its natural habitat in old-growth forests. Since it grows on wood, you should mimic this by maintaining damp wood or wooden substitutes in a controlled environment. Excess watering is not a concern like with soil-based plants, but ensure that the wood remains moist with periodic misting or soaking. Avoid letting it dry out completely as it thrives in consistently damp conditions."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Laricifomes officinalis naturally grows in forested areas where sunlight is filtered and indirect. It prefers low-light conditions, similar to the shaded environments on the trunks of conifer trees. In cultivation, it doesn’t require direct sunlight, which can dry out the fungal growth and the host wood. Keeping it in a shaded area with only ambient light mimicking the dappled sunlight of a forest canopy will promote healthy growth. Protect it from strong, direct sunlight to avoid desiccation and stress."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Laricifomes officinalis is not necessary in the traditional sense as it is a fungus, not a plant with branches or leaves that need trimming. However, managing its growth involves removing any decayed sections or trimming back the mycelium when it overgrows its designated space. This also helps prevent contamination and maintain health. Regular inspection and careful removal of unwanted growth ensure that the fungus thrives and continues to grow healthily on its host wood."}],"care_level":"Extreme","common_name":"Quinine Conk","description":"Laricifomes officinalis is a wood-decay fungus in the order Polyporales. It causes brown heart rot on conifers, and is found in Europe, Asia, and North America, as well as Morocco. It is commonly known as agarikon, as well as the quinine conk because of its extremely bitter taste. DNA analysis supports L. officinalis as distinct from the genus Fomitopsis.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"High","origin":["North America","Europe"],"other_name":["Quinine Conk"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":[],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Laricifomes officinalis"],"soil":["Well-drained","Moist"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Water the plant thoroughly once the top inch of soil feels dry to the touch. During winter dormancy, reduce watering frequency to prevent overwatering, allowing the soil to dry out slightly between waterings. Using rainwater or distilled water is preferable, as Alpine Bartsia may be sensitive to the impurities found in tap water."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Bartsia alpina prefers a location with full sun to partial shade, depending on the climate. In cooler climates, full sun is ideal as it helps the plant to thrive and produce vibrant blooms. In warmer climates, providing some afternoon shade is beneficial to protect the plant from intense heat. If grown in an alpine or rock garden setting, ensure it's placed in a spot where it receives at least 6 hours of sunlight each day. The plant can tolerate dappled light but avoid heavy shade as this can hinder its growth and blooming potential."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Bartsia alpina involves removing dead or damaged stems and leaves to encourage healthy growth. This should be done in early spring before the new growth emerges or in late autumn after the plant begins to die back for winter. Use clean, sharp scissors or pruning shears to avoid damaging the plant. Regular deadheading, or removing spent flowers, can also help prolong blooming and improve the plant’s appearance. However, avoid excessive pruning as Bartsia alpina generally prefers a more natural form and doesn't require heavy pruning."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Velvetbells","description":"Bartsia alpina is a species of perennial flowering plant. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":14711,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies","Birds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Rubus occidentalis, commonly known as black raspberry, prefers well-drained soil with consistent moisture, especially during the growing season. Water young plants regularly to help them establish a strong root system. Once established, black raspberries require about an inch of water per week, either from rainfall or supplemental watering. Be sure to water deeply at the base of the plant to encourage deep root growth. Mulching can help retain soil moisture and reduce the need for frequent watering. Avoid overhead watering, as wet foliage can increase the risk of fungal diseases."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Rubus occidentalis thrives in full sun, requiring at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight daily to produce an abundant crop of berries. Full sun exposure is crucial for optimal fruit development and sugar content in the berries. While black raspberries can tolerate partial shade, too much shade will result in fewer fruits and a weaker plant structure. Ensure the planting site provides adequate sunlight throughout the day, and avoid areas with heavy shade from trees or buildings. Proper sunlight ensures healthy growth and productivity."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Rubus occidentalis is essential for maintaining plant health and encouraging fruit production. In early spring, before new growth begins, prune out dead, damaged, or weak canes. After harvesting in summer, cut back the canes that fruited to the ground, as they will not produce again. During the growing season, remove any new canes that appear outside the desired plant area. In mid-summer, tip prune the new canes to encourage lateral branching, which increases fruit yield. Proper pruning improves air circulation, reducing the risk of disease."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"black raspberry","description":"Rubus occidentalis is a species of Rubus native to eastern North America. Its common name black raspberry is shared with the closely related western American species Rubus leucodermis. Other names occasionally used include wild black raspberry, black caps, black cap raspberry, thimbleberry, and scotch cap.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Black\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Summer","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["black raspberry"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Cane borers","Raspberry crown borer"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Rubus occidentalis"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}
