{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":15010,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Hieracium gronovii, commonly known as hawkweed, prefers moderately moist conditions but is relatively drought-tolerant once established. It is important to water this plant when the topsoil feels dry to the touch, typically once a week during the growing season. However, be cautious not to overwater, as standing water can lead to root rot. During the dormant winter months, reduce watering significantly, allowing the soil to dry out almost completely between watering sessions. The key is to maintain a balance where the soil is neither completely dry nor persistently soggy."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Hieracium gronovii thrives in full sun to partial shade. For optimal growth, provide at least 6 hours of direct sunlight per day. Full sun promotes more vibrant flowering and a more compact growth habit. In regions with particularly hot or harsh afternoon sun, slight afternoon shade can be beneficial to prevent leaf scorching. However, if grown in too much shade, the plant may become leggy and produce fewer flowers. Therefore, a location that receives morning sun and some afternoon shade, or full sun all day, is ideal for this plant's health and blooming potential."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Hieracium gronovii mainly involves deadheading spent flowers to encourage further blooming and to prevent the plant from self-seeding if you do not want it to spread aggressively. This can be done by cutting the flower stalk down to the base after blooming. Additionally, you can prune to remove any damaged or diseased foliage throughout the season. In the fall, after the growing season has ended, you can cut back any dead foliage to tidy the plant and prepare it for the winter months. Regular removal of spent flowers and damaged foliage helps maintain plant health and appearance."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Hairy Hawkweed","description":"Hieracium gronovii or queendevil is a North American plant species in the dandelion tribe within the sunflower family. It is common and widespread across much of the continent from Ontario south as far as Florida, the Dominican Republic, and Panamá.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["Hairy Hawkweed"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Hieracium gronovii"],"soil":["Well-drained","Rocky","Gravelly"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

During its growing season in spring and summer, water the plant regularly to keep the soil consistently moist, but not waterlogged. This plant is quite drought-tolerant once established, so reduce watering in the fall and winter. Ensure that the soil has good drainage to prevent root rot. Overwatering can lead to fungal issues, so it's important to allow the top inch of the soil to dry out between watering sessions. Adjust your watering schedule according to rainfall and temperature fluctuations."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Maximilian sunflower thrives in full sun conditions, requiring at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight each day to perform optimally. The plant can tolerate some light shade, but insufficient sunlight may result in weaker stems and reduced flowering. When planting Helianthus maximiliani, select a location that gets plenty of bright, unfiltered sunlight. Sun exposure not only helps in vigorous growth but also enriches the vibrancy of its yellow blooms. If indoor growing is necessary, a south-facing window would provide the necessary sunlight exposure to sustain healthy flowering and growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Helianthus maximiliani helps maintain its shape and promotes healthy growth. It's best to prune back dead and damaged stems in early spring before new growth starts. During the growing season, deadhead spent flowers to encourage continued blooming. Toward the end of the growing season after flowering, you can trim the plant back more significantly to prepare it for winter. This perennial regenerates each year, so removing some of the older, woodier stems will allow it to thrive. Be careful not to cut the plant back too early in fall, as it can affect next year's growth."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Maximilian sunflower","description":"Helianthus maximiliani is a North American species of sunflower known by the common name Maximilian sunflower.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"High","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["Maximilian sunflower"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot","Powdery mildew"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Helianthus maximiliani"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

It prefers consistently damp to wet soil conditions and should be watered regularly to maintain these conditions. During dry spells or in hot weather, additional watering may be necessary to keep the soil sufficiently moist. When growing indoors or in containers, ensure good drainage to prevent waterlogging, which can harm the plant's roots. Monitoring the soil's moisture level and adjusting watering accordingly is crucial for maintaining healthy growth."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Cyperus echinatus thrives in full sun to partial shade. It can tolerate a range of light conditions but performs best when exposed to several hours of bright, direct sunlight each day. If grown indoors, placing the plant near a south or east-facing window can help it receive adequate light. In areas with intense midday sun, providing some shade during the hottest parts of the day can prevent leaf scorching. Balancing sunlight exposure is key to ensuring robust growth and preventing etiolation, where the plant becomes leggy and weak."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Cyperus echinatus is primarily aimed at maintaining its appearance and removing any dead or damaged stalks. Regularly check the plant for stalks that have dried out or become discolored, and trim these down to the base using clean, sharp scissors or pruning shears. If the plant becomes overly dense, thinning out some of the stalks can help improve air circulation and reduce disease risk. Pruning should be done cautiously to prevent excessive removal of healthy stalks, which are necessary for photosynthesis and overall plant vitality."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Globe Flatsedge","description":"Cyperus echinatus is a species of plant in the sedge family. It is native to much of the eastern United States, primarily in the lower Mississippi Valley and the lowland plain east of the southern Appalachians, with scattered populations in Florida and as far north as Wisconsin and the Adirondacks. Additional isolated populations occur in southern Mexico. It is found in a variety of sunny, often mesic habitats.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["Globe Flatsedge"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":[],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Cyperus echinatus"],"soil":["Well-drained","Moist"],"watering_period":"Evening"}}

In early spring, before new growth begins, cut back any old or dead stems to encourage fresh growth. During the growing season, trimming back overly long stems can help maintain the plant’s shape and prevent it from becoming too leggy. Late fall pruning is not usually necessary, as the plant will die back naturally in winter. Always use clean, sharp tools to avoid damaging the plant."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"leafcup","description":"Polymnia canadensis, commonly known as whiteflower leafcup, is a flowering plant native to eastern North America from Ontario south to Alabama and from Kansas, Oklahoma, and Minnesota east to North Carolina, Vermont and Connecticut. However, if kept in cultivated settings, trimming back dead or decaying sections gently can help maintain host plant health and aesthetics. Care should be taken not to disturb the host plant's root system, which is vital for the parasite's survival. Regular monitoring and minimal interference generally suffice, ensuring the plant naturally completes its life cycle, which includes flowering and seeding phases for propagation."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Northern Groundcone","description":"Boschniakia rossica, commonly known as the northern groundcone, is a holoparasitic plant that lives in the northern latitudes of the northern hemisphere. It does not contain chlorophyll, so it must be parasitic to obtain nutrients.
